Wes Bonelli

About

I'm an IT professional trained in computer science and psychology, with 4+ years of experience developing software for research and enterprise. I'm presently most interested in the philosophy, psychology, and praxis of human ecology in the context of environmental crisis mitigation/adaptation. Other interests include:
  • Applied mathematics (category theory, linear control systems)
  • Data visualization
  • Linguistics/literature/semiotics
  • Philosophy of science
  • Social/cognitive psychology and cognitive science
I write things here sometimes. Usually I have no relevant qualifications to do so. Please don't hesitate to point out why I'm obviously mistaken and I'll do my best to fix it.

Contact

wpbonelli@gmail.com | wpb3hw@virginia.edu

Github | LinkedIn | ResearchGate

Software

  • CSPID

    CSPID (pronounced “speedy”) is a C# PID (proportional-integral-derivative) controller targeting .NET Standard 2.0.

  • Sensus

    Sensus is an end-to-end crowd-sensing solution for iOS/Android.

Publications

  • P. Chow, W. Bonelli, Y. Huang, K. Fua, B. Teachman, and L. E. Barnes. “DEMONS: An Integrated Framework for Examining Associations between Physiology and Self-Reported Affect Tied to Depressive Symptoms.” In: Proceedings of the 2016 ACM International Joint Conference on Pervasive and Ubiquitous Computing: Adjunct. ACM, 2016, pp. 1139-1143

  • E. Geyer, K. Fua, K. Daniel, P. Chow, W. Bonelli, Y. Huang, L. E. Barnes, and B. Teachman. “I Did OK, but Did I Like It? Using Ecological Momentary Assessment to Examine Perceptions of Social Interactions Associated With Severity of Social Anxiety and Depression.” In: Behavior Therapy. 2018.

  • P. Chow, K. Fua, H. Xiong, W. Bonelli, B. Teachman, and L. E. Barnes. “SAD: Social Anxiety and Depression Dynamic Monitoring System.” In: Computing and Mental Health Workshop, CHI: ACM Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems. 2016, pp. 1-4.

  • P. Chow, K. Fua, Y. Huang, W. Bonelli, H. Xiong, L. E. Barnes, and B. Teachman. “Using Mobile Sensing to Test Clinical Models of Depression, Social Anxiety, State Affect, and Social Isolation.” In: Journal of Medical Internet Research. 2017.

Blog

Morton suggests we think human-in-the-loop systems like toys: things to play with, share with one another (not kill one another over), and which we may grow out of at some point ("there's no one toy to rule them all"). I like to think words this way. All appearing here are artifacts of an ongoing process and ought not be considered complete or definitive (though I will make clear if/when something has been edited retroactively).

  • Spirography (04 Dec 2019)

  • Words (25 Nov 2019)
